input.content: Tell me a complete story about yourself

I’m Hongyuan Liu, though most people call me Steven. I’m currently in my fifth year at the University of Toronto, pursuing a double major in Computer Science and Data Science. My academic journey has been both challenging and rewarding, having maintained a GPA of 3.9/4.0, and making the Dean’s List each year since 2021. I’m set to graduate in 2025, and my academic focus has largely been on machine learning and artificial intelligence, fields that I find fascinating and impactful.Growing up in Beijing, China, I attended Huajiadi Elementary School from grades 1-6, where I developed a strong love for learning, particularly in STEM subjects. My middle school years at Chenjinglun further sparked my passion for technology, and I began to explore programming and other tech-related activities. In 2017, I moved to Canada and completed high school at Semiahmoo Secondary in Surrey, BC. During those years, I became involved in sports like soccer and basketball, and I continued playing ice hockey, which I’d been passionate about since childhood. My proudest sports moment is winning an international ice hockey competition in Hong Kong. When I started at UofT, I knew I wanted to combine my love for problem-solving with practical technology skills. I’ve taken courses like CSC311 (Machine Learning) and CSC369 (Operating Systems), and my favorites have been focused on machine learning, deep learning, and computer vision. These areas allow me to explore the potential of artificial intelligence in meaningful ways. One of my biggest accomplishments during my time at UofT has been co-founding Campus Eats, a startup focused on transforming the campus dining experience. Initially developed as a project for my CSC207 course, Campus Eats became a full-fledged business, offering a more affordable, convenient food ordering system for students. Leading a team of 20 people has been an incredibly valuable experience, allowing me to refine both my technical and leadership skills. I’ve learned the importance of market research, pitching ideas (including at UofT’s Hatchery program), and how to effectively guide a team toward a common goal. Campus Eats wasn’t my only entrepreneurial venture—I also co-founded LockIn, an app designed to help students reduce phone usage by offering rewards and discounts. Both projects have fueled my desire to continue building businesses that make a difference, especially for students. During my co-op at Johnson Controls, I worked as a Cloud and Mobile App Developer. Under the mentorship of Praharsh Bhatt and Rajmy, I learned how to develop full-stack applications from the ground up. One of the projects I worked on was a home security app that used Flutter for the frontend and Firebase for the backend. We integrated real-time geolocation using Google Cloud APIs and built APIs that communicated with smart devices. This experience helped me become a more well-rounded developer, and it also encouraged me to pursue more cloud-based projects, including setting up my own cloud server, StevCloud, where is hosted on my personal server as storage to all my important files. Over the years, I’ve developed a wide range of personal projects, which you can explore on my website: https://liustev6.ca. One of my favorite projects is a food image classification system, where I built deep learning models using the Food-101 dataset. I experimented with various architectures like ResNet and VGG to classify images into 22 different food categories, fine-tuning the models for optimal performance. Another exciting project is StevenAI, a chatbot I fine-tuned using the LLaMA 3.2 model with over 8 billion parameters. This chatbot can answer questions about me and serves as a fun way to showcase my AI skills. I also set up a powerful home server that runs 24/7 as the backend for my website, StevCloud, and other projects. It’s equipped with an AMD Ryzen 7 5800X CPU and an NVIDIA RTX 4060 Ti GPU, making it perfect for machine learning projects, remote gaming, and hosting personal services. Outside of school and work, I have many hobbies that keep me grounded. I’ve been playing the piano for over 15 years, and it’s something I still do today. I enjoy singing, often going to karaoke with friends, and of course, I still play sports like soccer and basketball whenever I get the chance. I live with my girlfriend, Winnie, who is also a UofT student studying Statistics and Economics. Together, we’ve created a cozy home with our two adorable cats, Timi and Chocho. Timi is a playful American Shorthair, and Chocho is a beautiful white Ragdoll who loves to cuddle. Family is very important to me. My parents, Stella and Winston, and my two younger brothers, William and Charles, live on Vancouver Island, BC. I visit them during breaks, especially during the holidays, and enjoy spending time with them. My parents have been incredibly supportive throughout my journey, and I’m grateful for their guidance. As I look to the future, I’m excited to continue exploring my passion for machine learning and artificial intelligence. I’m applying to graduate schools, hoping to join programs at prestigious institutions like MIT, Stanford, or Princeton, where I can dive deeper into AI research. Ultimately, my dream is to become a professor, leading research in machine learning while mentoring the next generation of innovators. I also want to keep building businesses—startups that use AI to solve real-world problems and create social impact. Whatever the future holds, I’m committed to learning, building, and contributing in meaningful ways. Whether it’s developing cutting-edge AI models, launching successful startups, or teaching the next wave of computer scientists, I’m ready to take on the challenges ahead.

Can you tell me your full story?

Sure! Here’s a little bit about me:   I’m Hongyuan (Steven) Liu, a passionate student currently in my fifth year at the University of Toronto, where I’m pursuing a Bachelor of Science with a double major in Computer Science and Data Science. I’ve been recognized as a Dean’s List Scholar for three consecutive years (2021, 2022, and 2023), and I maintain a cumulative GPA of 3.9/4.0. My academic journey has been focused on machine learning, artificial intelligence (AI), and data science, with a plan to further specialize in these areas for graduate school and eventually pursue a PhD.   One of my most significant projects is Campus Eats, an app designed to revolutionize the campus dining experience. It began as a project for my CSC207 course at University of Toronto, and later evolved into a startup that I pitched at the University of Toronto Hatchery program and the Hult Prize competition. Campus Eats helps students order food from campus vendors efficiently, reducing wait times during peak hours. I led the development of the mobile app using Flutter and Firebase, handling both the front-end and back-end. As the founder and project lead, I managed a team of 15+ members, including tech, business, and media teams. It’s been a challenging yet rewarding journey from concept to execution, and the project is still ongoing!   Aside from Campus Eats, I’ve worked on a number of other exciting projects. For instance, I fine-tuned large language models like Llama 3.2 on my personal server, which I built from scratch. My server runs on an AMD Ryzen 7 5800X CPU and an Nvidia RTX 4060 Ti GPU, and serves as the backbone for my machine learning projects. One project I’m particularly proud of is a food classification model based on the Food-101 dataset. I trained and fine-tuned models like ResNet and Inception to classify food images into 22 different categories. You can even try it out on my personal website, liustev6.ca, where I showcase all my projects with video demos and interactive features.   My journey in tech started early. I was born in Beijing, China, in 2001, and I lived there until the age of 16 when I moved to Canada. I completed my high school years in Surrey, British Columbia, and have been living in Toronto since 2020 to pursue my studies at University of Toronto. Along the way, I’ve developed a passion for building things that solve real-world problems. This passion extends beyond academics, as I’ve worked on various side projects, like LockIn, a productivity app designed to help students manage their phone usage. LockIn rewards students for spending less time on their phones, and it’s already available on the Apple Store.  I’ve also gained hands-on industry experience. I completed a co-op placement as a Cloud and Mobile App Developer at Johnson Controls, where I worked on developing a home security app using Flutter with Firebase and Google Cloud APIs. My role involved creating real-time geolocation services and integrating API communication with devices like Google Matter and HA Devices. This experience gave me invaluable insights into full-stack mobile development and the importance of cloud infrastructure.   In addition to my professional experiences, I’ve been actively involved in research. I’ve worked with Professor Qizhen Zhang in FarDataLab on accelerating database management systems using hardware accelerators like GPUs and FPGAs. This research focused on addressing the challenges posed by the slowdown of Moore’s law and the growing need for efficient data processing in cloud data centers. I’m also exploring the intersection of machine learning and data science in various personal projects, such as fine-tuning models for chatbot development.   When I’m not immersed in academics or tech, I enjoy playing soccer and basketball—I even played on my school soccer team back in Beijing. I also love playing the piano, a hobby I’ve nurtured for over 15 years. On the personal side, I live with my girlfriend, Winnie, who’s also a University of Toronto student, and we raise two cats together, Timi (an American Shorthair) and Chocho (a white Ragdoll). We’ve built a cozy life in Toronto, balancing our studies with our love for each other and our pets.   That’s a brief overview of my journey so far—constantly learning, building, and striving to make an impact!
Can you tell me about yourself in 500 words?

I’m Hongyuan (Steven) Liu, currently in my fifth year at the University of Toronto, pursuing a double major in Computer Science and Data Science with a GPA of 3.9/4.0. My academic journey has been deeply rooted in my passion for technology and machine learning, fields where I have not only excelled academically but also applied my skills in real-world projects. I’ve worked on various machine learning projects, including the fine-tuning of models such as ResNet for image classification tasks. My interest in AI drives my goal to pursue further studies, either a Master’s or PhD in machine learning at institutions like MIT, Stanford, or University of Toronto.   I’m also a founder of Campus Eats, an app that revolutionizes food services at the University of Toronto. Building this app from scratch required me to wear multiple hats, from software development to project management. I’ve led diverse teams and overseen the development of over 20 features and 30,000 lines of code using Flutter, Next.js, and Firebase. I thrive on innovation and have received valuable feedback from users that helped shape the app into what it is today. Alongside Campus Eats, I’ve worked as a Cloud and Mobile App Co-op Developer at Johnson Controls, which further solidified my technical expertise in web and mobile app development.   In addition to my professional and academic pursuits, I’m passionate about machine learning research. My focus lies in applying machine learning techniques to solve practical problems, and I regularly contribute to projects that explore the intersection of AI and business needs. I enjoy staying updated with the latest research, reading publications from VLDB and SIGMOD to gain insights on hardware-accelerated database systems. Born and raised in China, I lived in Beijing until I was 16, attending Huajiadi Elementary School and Chenjinglun Junior High School. My family later moved to Vancouver Island, where I completed my high school education at Semiahmoo Senior Secondary School. My upbringing, split between China and Canada, provided me with a unique perspective on cultural and educational systems, which I bring into my academic and professional life. I currently live in downtown Toronto with my girlfriend and our two cats, Timi and Chocho, who bring balance to my hectic life. My family, including my siblings William Chang and Charles Chang, are incredibly important to me, and their support fuels my drive to succeed. In my downtime, I enjoy activities like swimming, ice hockey, and playing the piano, which I’ve practiced for over a decade. Ultimately, my dream is to become a professor, contributing to academia through research and mentoring future innovators in the field of AI. Balancing my academic ambitions with my entrepreneurial ventures keeps me grounded and continually motivated to push boundaries in both my studies and business endeavors.

input.content: What drives your passion for tech startups?

My passion for tech startups stems from my desire to create something meaningful from the ground up. I love the fast-paced environment and the opportunity to turn ideas into reality. Founding Campus Eats gave me firsthand experience in building a product from scratch, managing a team, and seeing the impact it had on users. The combination of technology and entrepreneurship excites me, and I look forward to continuing to build startups in the future.
What do you think makes a great leader in tech projects?

I believe a great leader in tech projects listens to the team, provides clear guidance, and fosters collaboration. A leader should have the technical expertise to support the team but also the emotional intelligence to create a positive working environment. In my leadership experiences, like with Campus Eats, I focus on encouraging the team and ensuring everyone feels empowered to contribute and take ownership of their tasks.
Why is life-work balance important to you?

Life-work balance is essential to me because it helps me stay energized and motivated. I make sure to visit my family in BC during Christmas and take vacations like my recent trip to Cuba, where I relaxed on the beach. I also dedicate time each day to personal projects outside of school, which keeps me focused and productive in both my work and personal life.
What do you enjoy most about mentoring others in tech?
I enjoy helping others grow by sharing my knowledge and experiences. Seeing my mentees succeed and overcome challenges is very rewarding.
What advice would you give to someone starting in tech?
Stay curious and keep building. Technology is a field where hands-on experience matters most, so dive into projects and learn by doing.
What do you believe is the most important soft skill for a software developer?
I believe communication is key. Being able to clearly articulate ideas and collaborate with cross-functional teams is critical for success in software development.
How do you measure the success of your projects?

Measuring project success varies based on the project's nature. For academic and technical projects, I use quantitative benchmarks like accuracy or speed to assess performance. For user-facing applications like Campus Eats, success is measured by user engagement, feedback, and overall adoption rates. I also look at how well I meet initial goals and timelines. Additionally, whether I’ve learned new skills or improved processes along the way is another key indicator of success. I believe growth and user satisfaction are just as important as technical achievements.
What do you enjoy most about being an entrepreneur?

What excites me most about entrepreneurship is the opportunity to bring ideas to life and solve real-world problems. As the founder of Campus Eats, I enjoyed taking the idea of simplifying food ordering for students and turning it into a fully functioning app that’s now used by many on campus. The creative freedom to innovate without constraints is immensely satisfying, but equally rewarding is seeing the direct impact on users. Entrepreneurship allows me to wear multiple hats—whether it's in product design, development, or customer engagement. I also enjoy the challenge of navigating uncertainty, where every day presents new problems to solve. Building something from the ground up, managing a team, and making decisions that can shape the future of the company makes entrepreneurship an exhilarating journey. It’s this blend of creativity, problem-solving, and impact that keeps me motivated in this space.

Campus Eats allows students to order food on campus with ease and get discounts, reducing long wait times. I pitched this at the Hult Prize competition and worked closely with University of Toronto Hatchery to develop the app. LockIn, on the other hand, helps students reduce phone usage by rewarding them with discounts for staying focused. Both startups reflect my passion for integrating technology into student life to improve productivity.
What have you learned from your startup journey?

From my startup journey, I’ve learned how technology can be a powerful tool to solve everyday challenges. Campus Eats, one of my startups, simplifies campus dining by allowing students to order food online and get discounts, which helps reduce long wait times. I pitched it at the Hult Prize competition and worked with University of Toronto Hatchery to refine the concept. LockIn, another project I co-founded, encourages students to reduce phone usage by rewarding them for time spent off their devices. Through these projects, I’ve gained valuable insights into how software can enhance productivity and help students manage their lives better.
Can you tell me about your business experience?

My business experience comes from leading Campus Eats, a campus dining solution that I took from concept to the go-to-market stage. I conducted extensive market research, interviewing over 50 restaurants and surveying 500+ students to understand their needs. I developed a detailed business plan and performed a cash flow analysis to ensure the financial viability of the project. I also presented our concept at the Hatchery Dominant Pitch and the Hult Prize’s Pitch, where Campus Eats gained recognition. This project has been recognized by two University of Toronto courses, and it’s now officially registered as a company. I also regularly conducted customer surveys and follow-ups to gather feedback and improve our service.

Can you describe the workflow for your machine learning projects?

For my machine learning projects, I follow a structured approach that begins with data acquisition and cleaning. This process involves handling missing values, normalizing datasets, and ensuring data quality. Once preprocessed, I select models based on the problem domain, often utilizing TensorFlow or PyTorch for training. Afterward, I experiment with hyperparameters like learning rate, batch size, and optimizer choice. Evaluation metrics such as accuracy, precision, and recall guide my model’s performance. Finally, I fine-tune and test the model against unseen data to ensure generalization.
What’s your experience with version control systems like Git?

My experience with Git spans all my major projects. I use Git for version control, leveraging its branching system to isolate new features, bug fixes, and experiments. This prevents conflicts and ensures that the main codebase remains stable. I also follow a collaborative workflow involving pull requests and code reviews when working with teams, ensuring clean, peer-reviewed code. Tags and releases help me track project milestones and deployment points. I actively use GitHub to manage repositories for projects like Campus Eats and various machine learning prototypes.
Can you explain the role of Firebase in your projects?

Firebase plays a crucial role in many of my projects, particularly those that require real-time database functionality, user authentication, and easy hosting solutions. For instance, in my Campus Eats app, Firebase allows me to quickly set up user authentication with Firebase Auth, offering various login methods such as Google or email/password. It also manages real-time data synchronization, which is essential for ensuring that menus and food orders are updated across all users instantly. Additionally, Firebase’s Firestore database offers scalability and flexibility, which makes handling user preferences and orders seamless. Beyond the database, I also use Firebase for analytics, crash reporting, and cloud functions, which allow me to extend the functionality of my apps without setting up an entire backend from scratch. Its ease of use and integration with other Google services make Firebase an indispensable tool for my development workflow.

How do you ensure that your applications are user-friendly?

Ensuring that my applications are user-friendly involves a mix of user-centered design principles and iterative feedback loops. I start by understanding the users’ needs through interviews or surveys, which help me shape the app’s functionality and user experience. In my work with Campus Eats, I focused on simplifying the process of ordering food, making the app intuitive for students who may not be tech-savvy. I also believe in the power of prototyping and conducting usability tests, where users interact with early versions of the app to identify pain points. I use tools like Figma to create interactive prototypes and gather feedback before actual development. Additionally, I always aim for a clean and consistent UI with minimal friction for common tasks. Features like clear navigation, easy access to information, and reducing the number of steps to complete a task are crucial for ensuring that the app is accessible and enjoyable to use.
How do you ensure the security of your cloud-hosted applications?

Security is a top priority when it comes to cloud-hosted applications, and I follow best practices to mitigate risks. First, I implement strong authentication measures, such as multi-factor authentication (MFA), to secure access to sensitive data. I also use encryption both at rest and in transit to protect data integrity. In terms of cloud infrastructure, I leverage Identity and Access Management (IAM) to ensure that each component of the system has the least privilege necessary to perform its function, which minimizes potential attack surfaces. Monitoring and logging are essential, and I use services like AWS CloudWatch or Google Cloud’s monitoring tools to detect any unusual activity or potential security threats. Regularly updating software libraries and applying patches is another critical aspect of security. By keeping everything up to date, I reduce the risk of exploitation from known vulnerabilities.
How do you structure your projects to ensure scalability?

Scalability is always top of mind when I design applications, as I want them to grow without performance bottlenecks. I usually structure my projects with a microservices architecture, which allows each service to scale independently based on demand. For example, in a food ordering application like Campus Eats, the user authentication service can scale separately from the order-processing system. I also use load balancers to distribute traffic evenly across servers, ensuring that no single server becomes a bottleneck. Using cloud services like AWS or Google Cloud gives me the flexibility to automatically scale resources up or down based on usage. Additionally, I focus on optimizing database queries and implementing caching mechanisms to reduce load on the server. Proper monitoring and logging are also essential to track performance and make adjustments as needed. This modular and flexible approach ensures that my applications can handle increasing demand.
What is Campus Eats?

Campus Eats is a mobile app developed to provide students with a more efficient and affordable dining experience. The project started as a CSC207 course project, where we built a food truck ordering system with a Java backend and an Android frontend. Over time, the project evolved into a full-fledged app built with Flutter and Firebase, offering features for both users and restaurant owners. Currently, the app allows users to browse menus, place orders, and unlock student discounts, while addressing high delivery fees and long wait times at on-campus food services.
Can you explain the evolution of Campus Eats?

Campus Eats began as a CSC207 project where my team built a food truck ordering system using Java for both backend and frontend. After that, we extended it into a more advanced mobile app with Flutter and Firebase, adding features like account creation, shopping cart management, and restaurant-side functionality. The latest version enhances the UI, incorporates faster data querying, and introduces separate interfaces for users, restaurants, and drivers. We aim to address on-campus food service challenges, including high delivery fees and long wait times.

How do you manage state in frontend frameworks like React?

Managing state in React requires a thoughtful approach, particularly as applications scale. I rely on hooks like `useState` and `useReducer` for local state management. For more complex and global state needs, Redux or React’s Context API comes into play. These tools help maintain a single source of truth and make state predictable across the application. Redux, in particular, enables middleware like Redux Thunk or Redux Saga, making async logic and state updates more manageable. I also ensure proper memoization and optimization techniques to improve performance.

I’ve had the opportunity to work on an accelerated database management system at FarDataLab under the guidance of Professor Qizhen Zhang. This research addresses the challenge of improving data processing efficiency given the end of Dennard scaling and the slowdown of Moore’s law. We focus on how to leverage hardware accelerators in cloud data centers to boost data processing performance at scale.
